text.tspan: The circle of life (of a file)
Knowing what is happening (from the command line)
With more complex yet super cool commands
For git, a file is either tracked (i.e. git
records its successive versions), or not.
Tracked files are in one of these states:
The typical life-cycle of a tracked file is:
The typical life-cycle of an untracked file is:
Recap: Life-cycle of a file, during a commit
A git commit is constituted of files snapshot + metadata.
If a single element (file content, date, author…) changes,
If two commits have different ID, for git they are totally
different (even if they might have the same files snapshot).
Recap: Anatomy of a git commit
git diff lets you see the difference in content between
two states of a single file.
It works on multiple files too, by appending all differences.
The default comparison granularity is the line of code.
Comparing word to word is also possible.
git status lets you see the state of each file in the repo
that is neither unmodified, nor ignored.
The verbose version (default) offer a reminder of commands
The --short (or -s) flag is useful for brevety.

tspan.tspan: is the exact undo of git add.

text.tspan: "Unmodifying" a file, using git checkout, is dangerous
git reset --hard is even more dangerous, because it deletes
Both git reset and git checkout can be applied on single
files or all of them. git reset --hard is on all files only.
Going back and forth in the process
